<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 292]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/32  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 298, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Further Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 30 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 392, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 485, 574]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 636, 777, 652]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 220, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 697, 380, 712]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 712, 728, 728]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(m\) is attached to one end of a light inextensible string of length \(a\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The string is held taut with \(OP\) making an angle \(\alpha\) with the downward vertical, where \(\cos \alpha = \frac{2}{3}\). The particle \(P\) is projected perpendicular to \(OP\) in an upwards direction with speed \(\sqrt{3ag}\) . It then starts to move along a circular path in a vertical plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 155, 920, 190]]<|/det|>
Find the cosine of the angle between the string and the upward vertical when the string first becomes slack. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 81, 630, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 332, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
A uniform lamina is in the form of a triangle \(ABC\) in which angle \(B\) is a right angle, \(AB = 9a\) and \(BC = 6a\) . The point \(D\) is on \(BC\) such that \(BD = x\) (see diagram). The region \(ABD\) is removed from the lamina. The resulting shape \(ADC\) is placed with the edge \(DC\) on a horizontal surface and the plane \(ADC\) is vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 409, 730, 431]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(x\), in terms of \(a\), for which the shape is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 411, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
One end of a light elastic string, of natural length \(a\) and modulus of elasticity \(\frac{16}{3} M g\), is attached to a fixed point \(O\). A particle \(P\) of mass \(4M\) is attached to the other end of the string and hangs vertically in equilibrium. Another particle of mass \(2M\) is attached to \(P\) and the combined particle is then released from rest. The speed of the combined particle when it has descended a distance \(\frac{1}{4} a\) is \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 161, 463, 180]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(v\) in terms of \(g\) and \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 161, 920, 180]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 156]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(5\mathrm{kg}\) moves along a horizontal straight line. At time \(t\mathrm{s}\), the velocity of \(P\) is \(\nu \mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) and its displacement from a fixed point \(O\) on the line is \(x\mathrm{m}\). The forces acting on \(P\) are a force of magnitude \(\frac{500}{\nu}\mathrm{N}\) in the direction \(OP\) and a resistive force of magnitude \(\frac{1}{2}\nu^2\mathrm{N}\) . When \(t = 0\), \(x = 0\) and \(\nu = 5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 168, 144, 186]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 168, 455, 186]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\nu\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected with speed \(u \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(\theta\) above the horizontal from a point \(O\) on a horizontal plane and moves freely under gravity. The horizontal and vertical displacements of \(P\) from \(O\) at a subsequent time \(t\) s are denoted by \(x \mathrm{m}\) and \(y \mathrm{m}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 138, 146, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 556, 157]]<|/det|>
Show that the equation of the trajectory is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 161, 425, 194]]<|/det|>
\[y = x\tan \theta -\frac{gx^2}{2u^2} (1 + \tan^2\theta).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 732, 89]]<|/det|>
In the subsequent motion \(P\) passes through the point with coordinates (30, 20).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 789, 120]]<|/det|>
Given that one possible value of \(\tan \theta\) is \(\frac{4}{3}\), find the other possible value of \(\tan \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 81, 845, 242]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 255, 920, 330]]<|/det|>
A light inextensible string is threaded through a fixed smooth ring \(R\) which is at a height \(h\) above a smooth horizontal surface. One end of the string is attached to a particle \(A\) of mass \(m\). The other end of the string is attached to a particle \(B\) of mass \(\frac{6}{7} m\). The particle \(A\) moves in a horizontal circle on the surface. The particle \(B\) hangs in equilibrium below the ring and above the surface (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 341, 920, 376]]<|/det|>
When \(A\) has constant angular speed \(\omega\), the angle between \(AR\) and \(BR\) is \(\theta\) and the normal reaction between \(A\) and the surface is \(N\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 920, 427]]<|/det|>
When \(A\) has constant angular speed \(\frac{3}{2}\omega\), the angle between \(AR\) and \(BR\) is \(\alpha\) and the normal reaction between \(A\) and the surface is \(\frac{1}{2} N\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 445, 144, 464]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 364, 464]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\cos \theta = \frac{4}{9}\cos \alpha\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 445, 920, 464]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 71, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 82, 756, 227]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 238, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
Two uniform smooth spheres \(A\) and \(B\) of equal radii have masses \(m\) and \(\frac{1}{2} m\) respectively. The two spheres are moving on a horizontal surface when they collide. Immediately before the collision, sphere \(A\) is travelling with speed \(u\) and its direction of motion makes an angle \(\alpha\) with the line of centres. Sphere \(B\) is travelling with speed \(2u\) and its direction of motion makes an angle \(\beta\) with the line of centres (see diagram). The coefficient of restitution between the spheres is \(\frac{5}{8}\) and \(\alpha + \beta = 90^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 146, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 339, 920, 374]]<|/det|>
Find the component of the velocity of \(B\) parallel to the line of centres after the collision, giving your answer in terms of \(u\) and \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 375]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
## Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 101, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
